column1: JWK stands for {{c1::JSON Web Key::standard name}} and provides a {{c2::uniform way to exchange public/private keys::purpose}} between systems in {{c3::JSON format::format}}.
column2: Unlike PEM format which is text-based with BEGIN/END markers, JWKs are native JSON objects. Used extensively in OAuth2/OIDC where identity providers publish public keys via JWKS endpoints at /.well-known/jwks.json for JWT verification.

column1: JWT stands for {{c1::JSON Web Token::standard name}}, a compact {{c2::URL-safe::transport property}} means of representing {{c3::claims::data type}} to be transferred between parties. JWTs are {{c4::stateless and self-contained::key characteristic}}.
column2: JWTs consist of three base64url-encoded parts: header.payload.signature. Unlike session cookies that require server-side session storage, JWTs carry all necessary information within themselves. Common in modern auth flows, especially microservices where services can verify tokens without calling a central auth server.

column1: The fundamental difference: JWK is {{c1::a key representation format::purpose}}, while JWT is {{c2::a signed/encrypted data token::purpose}}.
column2: Think of JWK as the key itself (like a physical key) and JWT as the locked box (the data). You use a JWK private key to sign a JWT and a JWK public key to verify it. JWKs are reusable cryptographic material, JWTs are single-use data containers. In practice, identity providers publish JWKs at /.well-known/jwks.json for clients to verify JWTs.

column1: A JWK object contains the {{c1::kty::required field}} field indicating key type and {{c2::key-specific material::content}}. For RSA keys, required fields are {{c3::n (modulus) and e (exponent)::RSA components}}. Optional fields include {{c4::kid, alg, use::metadata fields}}.
column2: Supported kty values: RSA, EC, oct (symmetric), OKP, none. For EC keys: crv (curve), x, y are required. The kid (key ID) is crucial for key rotation as it helps match JWT headers to specific keys in a JWKS. Example: {"kty":"RSA","n":"whYOFK2...","e":"AQAB","kid":"2024-01"}

column1: JWKS (JSON Web Key Set) is {{c1::a collection of JWKs::definition}} exposed at a {{c2::public endpoint::access type}} for {{c3::key discovery and rotation::purpose}}. To verify a JWT, match the {{c4::kid::JWT header field}} claim to a JWK in the set.
column2: JWKS structure: {"keys":[{jwk1},{jwk2}]}. OAuth2/OIDC providers typically expose JWKS at /.well-known/jwks.json. This enables seamless key rotation without updating every client application. Libraries like jose provide createRemoteJWKSet(url) for automatic fetching and caching.

column1: To sign a JWT, you import the {{c1::JWK private key::key type}} and pass it to the signing function with {{c2::claims::payload}} and {{c3::protected header::metadata}}. The JWK must contain {{c4::private key components::requirement}} (d for RSA).
column2: Using jose: const privateKey = await importJWK(jwk, 'RS256'); const jwt = await new SignJWT({claim: true}).setProtectedHeader({alg: 'RS256'}).sign(privateKey); The resulting JWT header contains alg and optionally kid to reference the key, but never the full key material itself.

column1: To verify a JWT, you import the {{c1::JWK public key::key type}} and pass it to the verification function. The JWK must be {{c2::public only::key requirement}} (no d component). Verification checks the {{c3::signature::cryptographic check}} and optionally validates {{c4::claims like iss, aud, exp::JWT validation}}.
column2: Using jose: const publicKey = await importJWK(jwk, 'RS256'); const {payload, protectedHeader} = await jwtVerify(jwt, publicKey, {issuer: 'urn:example:issuer', audience: 'urn:example:audience'}); For RSA public keys: only n and e are present, no d (private exponent).

column1: JWK thumbprint is a {{c1::hash-based identifier::type}} calculated from {{c2::specific JWK parameters::source}}, providing a {{c3::deterministic way to reference keys::purpose}} independent of kid. Fields must be {{c4::sorted alphabetically::requirement}} in canonical JSON.
column2: For RSA keys, thumbprint uses SHA-256 hash of only required fields: {"e":"AQAB","kty":"RSA","n":"..."}. Use cases: content-addressable key storage, detecting duplicate keys across systems, or when you need a stable identifier that doesn't depend on optional metadata like kid.

column1: Converting a JWK private key to public involves {{c1::removing private key components::operation}} (d, p, q, dp, dq, qi for RSA) while keeping {{c2::public parameters::what to keep}} (kty, n, e). Never expose JWKs with the {{c3::d parameter::critical security}}.
column2: Using jose: const publicJwk = privateJwk.toPublic(). This is essential when publishing public keys in JWKS endpoints while keeping private keys secure server-side. A leaked d parameter means your private key is compromised and can be used to forge signatures.

column1: In OAuth2/OIDC, identity providers {{c1::publish JWKs at /.well-known/jwks.json::IdP responsibility}} and clients {{c2::fetch JWKs to verify JWTs::client responsibility}} without {{c3::pre-shared secrets::security model}}. Clients match JWT {{c4::kid header::matching field}} to find the correct JWK.
column2: Flow: 1) User authenticates, receives JWT with kid in header. 2) Client fetches JWKS from IdP endpoint. 3) Client finds JWK matching kid. 4) Verifies JWT signature. This enables zero-trust architecture where clients only need the public JWKS URL. Libraries like jose provide createRemoteJWKSet(url) for automatic fetching and caching.
